job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Rochester, NY
pros: Takes pride in taking care of the work environment & you can cross train.
cons: As an RN I was a token in two units- the oncology unit & the CVICU unit. I came to the hospital with experience, really good post surgical experience from a busy busy hospital, let’s just say charge nurse would have 7 patients, day shift…wild I know, but that was the case. Honestly I was well prepared to advance on my skill set at this hospital. When I started on oncology and had worked there for a full year. I was the only black nurse. New grad white nurses would come & would soon be offered & trained to be charge. I was overlooked & never offered to train for charge in that unit. Basically never the opportunity for advancement for a black nurse as myself- this made me question my loyalty to the organization & if I wanted to stay with the hospital. There were a few staff that were passive aggressive & never included me in anything, including learning. It felt lonely working here. I switched to the CVICU…this was even worse- there was no black nurse there & no black tech (they had LPNs as techs). See I possibly got the opportunity because my name doesn’t come across as black/ it’s British so it’s never until someone sees me that they realize “oh she’s black”. Anyway, I wasn’t even given the opportunity to complete my orientation…my preceptor felt that I was so bad that the brand new grad nurses (white) were better and could stay so not only was I dealing with a preceptor creating a hostile work environment for me & yelling at me infront of patients & colleagues, my preceptorship was escalated to another staff another white manager lady who never even said hello to me (passive aggressive) & precepted me for one day….ONE DAY & told me that I was going to be walked off the unit the next day. With this aggressive yet subtle knowledge she shared, basically, I drafted my resignation letter & resigned that next day. I ended up taking travel opportunities & manager’s at these other top institutions thought I was so great that they always extended my contract & even offered me perm staff positions. & I now work as a staff at the nation’s top hospitals with true diversity & inclusion from doctors to nurses to management. & I can see how this has strengthened ability to stay with a hospital. If you look at some of the great orgs like NYU, Weill Cornell, NYP, Columbia, United Nations…one thing they share in common is there strengths in diversity & inclusion. This can be a great hospital if it can actually implement diversity & inclusion across all units & levels…& not just talk about it.

review_title: Many benefits to working here, but don't expect anything extra when the going gets tough
pros: Many opportunities for growth - internal transfers, educational opportunities and tuition benefits, world class innovation. Large teaching hospital that gets the sickest patients, great for learning.
cons:
When push comes to shove staff are simply not compensated adequately for what is asked of them. Constantly asked to do more with less. COVID was very eye opening, no hazard pay offered to designated COVID units even though other regional health systems did (ie. Buffalo and Syracuse). A 'market adjustment' was made to salaries during COVID to placate nursing (after taking away yearly raises, so really, we just broke even with where we would have been with an annual increase, slick move CFO) and it still does not compete with neighboring regional networks. Poor management is allowed to stay in place despite repeated complaints to HR and executive staff. There are some truly toxic work environments here, not everywhere, but if you're reading this you know who you are... Politics politics politics. I used to think the health benefits were good, until they created 3 different deductible tiers which forces you to use UR providers or break up your in-network deductible = never ending out of pocket expenses. Listening to attending physicians complain about their poor compensation, which is still 6-10x higher than what UR nurses make.

Final thoughts: if an institution can afford to pay exorbitant rates for travelers they can afford to compensate their nursing staff fairly during a pandemic, many of whom left for said travel contracts elsewhere when UR refused hazard pay, took away annual increases, AND reduced retirement contributions.

job_title: Licensed Pharmacy Technician in Rochester, NY
pros: My department is amazing! My fellow co-workers are nice, friendly, & willing to answer all my questions. It's the best of learning pharmacy without the stress of corporate greed & rude customers. Patient safety is 100% top priority! And the benefit package is amazing!
cons: Honestly, the only thing I can think of is having to pay for parking. As employees, I really think we shouldn't have to pay for that.

pros: If you work in the right department, once or twice a year you will get a free ice cream or voucher to a food truck. Hooray.
cons:
-They charge YOU to come to work. Parking passes range from hundreds of dollars to thousands each year. Oh your assigned lot is so far you have to take a bus in? Tough, can't clock in until you get all the way here. They also laid off most of the parking staff so now half of the parking spots are unusable. But the cost of a parking pass continue to INCREASE. Plus whether you're allowed in certain parking lots depends on your job. They're extremely elitist.

-"Raises" range from 1-2% yearly. That's how much doing a good or a bad job matters. 1% difference.

-Bureaucracy gets in the way of everything. Need 3 admins to sign off on one form to get something done. You want a raise? Sorry out of my hands, can't do anything about it. You'd have to talk to several different departments.

-If you apply for a different job with them while currently working for them, HR will adjust the salary based on your current salary. And since they have such a large monopoly on healthcare in the area, there's no escape.

-They will complain about not having money, needing to make cutbacks, laying staff off, and then turn around and build a whole new building that they somehow had the funds for.

-They pay their higher-ups exorbitant amounts of money (look it up, it is public record), claiming they work 80 hours a week?? I don't know how they are allowed to be called a non-profit.

-They don't care if you are understaffed. They just don't care. No matter what the issue is there will always be some other department or some other higher-up who is "tying their hands" so that they're unable to do anything about it.

-The benefits SEEM good, until you actually look into them:
>Tuition benefits (Only if you KEEP WORKING throughout and only if it relates to your job according to your supervisor, max of 2 classes at a time. Oh and often the money you "saved" is actually considered a taxable wage so you have to pay taxes on it as if you were paid it. Which is according to them, 41.35% of the tuition amount... )
>Healthcare -> Two plan options are you either get the cheap plan if you rarely go to the doctor and hope you won't need to, or the expensive plan and lose around ~$100 every 2 weeks to it.
>Child care program (run by them, duh) you get a 10% discount on their already jacked-up prices compared to everywhere else.

review_title: One of largest employers in Rochester and one of the worst
pros: If you are thinking of going to school, it could be a decent option as they help with tuition. That’s honestly about it!
cons: I don’t know even know where to begin! I worked for this employer for almost 5 years in various departments and it is just all around bad! Extreme understaffing and over working and they do not compensate employees well at all! But I would say the worst part is parking! You are forced to park in a lot over 3 miles away from the hospital, and you have to pay for! There is a shuttle service that, if you could access the complaint records probably had 100s everyday. The drivers are aggressive and nasty, they are always late and even skip routes when they think they can get away with it. It only runs certain hours so if you end up working late you can risk missing it with absolutely NO way to get to your vehicle! You could not even walk if you wanted as the Route is in a bad area (there are constant robbings reported) and is dangerous, unsafe to walk no side walks and busy traffic and not light! This is an extreme hazard and they are asking for someone to be killed! When you call the parking department and complain they tell you they contract the shuttle through RTS therefore they are not responsible! How is it that I pay YOU for a service and YOU are not responsible, they use RTS as a scapegoat! Very nasty people both shuttle drivers and parking department! That alone should deter you from this company!

job_title: Outpatient Access Associate in Rochester, NY
pros: Some of my coworkers were cool folks, pay was OK and benefits were good. Sometimes they would buy a pizza and put it in a break room to try to buy us off. The pizza was from Mr. Shoe's usually, which has some of the best pizza in Rochester, BUT the gesture was transparent and demeaning. Internal transfers are easier than getting hired from outside.
cons: Management is usually incompetent and indifferent to you at best, but generally erring on the side of hostility-- it's all about the bottom line and employees are assets, not people. NEVER listens to them or considers them in decisions. My department found out a major new system was going live literally 2 HOURS beforehand, leaving the employees at the bottom of the chain scrambling to cover everything-- this happened twice in the span of six months. HR department is basically composed of latter-day Pharisees who are more concerned with employee regulations than with actual employees (Typical, I'm sure, but still disconcerting-- they don't even try to pretend otherwise). The workplace culture is generally fairly negative, people there will throw each other under the bus in a heartbeat if they think it'll ingratiate them to higher-ups, who will then proceed without hesitation to throw their employee under the bus to their own higher-up. When they aren't throwing you under the bus, they're passing the buck to try to earn their paycheck for as little work as possible. CONSTANTLY understaffed, which meant pressure to pick up "voluntary" (in name only) overtime shifts on weekends and evenings.

review_title: If you want to be a Puppet
pros: Areas largest employer and the reputation it holds in the community makes you proud to be part of the organization.  But like most things the closer you look the corruption and thievery is evident.
cons: I have worked in numerous departments with this facility and it is all the same game.  Management like to tag you as a character and berate you into that role.  If you do not comply it will excel into intimidation and alienation.  I have had EAP & Human Resources involved in one-on-one meetings and management continue that same behavior in front of them.  I was instructed to never be behind closed doors with them without representation, however, managements behavior did not change in their company.  TWISTED!

review_title: Worked for 2 years as a Student Worker in the Cardiac Surgery Dept.
pros: Very cordial environment to work in. Flexible hours considering I was a student worker and I looked up at the staff as family. Though it was not part of the requirements, I was once asked if I wanted to sit in on a live heart transplant surgery and I would say that watching a dead heart restarting to give back life to someone shall forever remain the best experience I have had in my life so far.
cons: As a student worker, my presence was on an  on-need basis which was limited by student work hour limits. This was inconvenient because some weeks there would be more work than time available and other weeks vice versa. This was much less of a fallacy and more of a consequence of the positions requirement per se. Not really a con, I would say.

review_title: Frustrating, low pay, false promises, little advancement, impressive research
pros: The benefit packages are nice. I have great health insurance. If your boss will allow you to take classes, there are some tuition benefits. There are a lot of smart people doing research here. I know of one PI that will receive a Nobel some day. There are a lot of great seminars, presentations, conferences throughout the year.
cons: Lower pay than similar jobs elsewhere. Each department/lab is disjoint from the next. Some areas do reviews and raises less frequently than others. I was promised raises and promotions that wouldn't come. Had to get HR involved. Not a lot of team building. Can be a "fend for yourself" environment. I found that the lab I work in brings out the worst in people because of the way it is managed. Not easy to advance and be promoted.

review_title: Work environment probably very typical to other large academic medical centers
pros:
Lab space, facilities and resources
Benefits: retirement and time off very good, health care pretty good
Mentally stimulating work
cons:
Parking: cost, faraway, 3 deep 
Difficult to advance career or get a raise
Large bureaucracy creates multiple hoops to jump through to get things done
Pay could be more competitive
Suspect women in research are being paid less than their male counterparts
Issues employees had with sexual harassment weren't dealt with properly until after negative media attention... still needs improvement
Funding issues compounded by the number of expenses the university charges for out of grants on-top of the overhead they already take out
Science funding is an ongoing national struggle that is not the university's fault
Lab Technicians are under valued
Academic research culture can be very dysfunctional (again a national problem)

review_title: Not a bad place to work.
job_title: Information Analyst II in Rochester, NY
pros: My job is flexible with the hours, time off, etc. So that is the best part. The benefits are ok - better than most companies in the Rochester area, however, those are being tightened a bit. Employees are now having to pay more toward their health insurance, and more toward tuition benefits than they did 5 years ago. I'm pretty securely employed, so I can't really complain. However, at an institution this large, employee appreciation is minimal.
cons: Poor raises, based on job title. They don't even cover the rising cost of living expenses... or the ever rising parking rates. Salaries are capped. It's very hard to get a job here. I, as well as a couple people I know have applied to countless positions and never hear a word back.

job_title: Building Mechanic A in Rochester, NY
pros: Decent pay, great benefits....always have work to do, it's one job to the next, usually multiple jobs at once have to be balanced which is good if you like a challenge.
cons: You literally have to know someone to get in. Mega corporate, although they play the "non-profit card" to its fullest extent. Very bureaucratic, tons of red tape just to get simple tasks completed; you need 15 signatures to order a pair of scissors for a job. Obviously you have to work around people who are constantly sick, it is a hospital, so be prepared mentally and emotionally. Lack of diversity in certain departments. Constantly hiring friends, family, and former employees that they already know. If you do make it, welcome to the "Good ole boys" club....very clicky almost like high school. It's hard to positively challenge or question superiors without repercussions; military-like chain of command style management. Difficult to get promoted due to nepotism.

job_title: ISD System Administrator in Rochester, NY
pros:
Company has good benefits,  flexible work arrangements (to a certain degree), generous time off  with the ability to roll over.  
If you have a family and want a decent environment to work in, are willing to put up with a lot of "politics" then check this company out.  You'll really need to love meetings and bureaucracy.
You'll need to check your brain at the door and become a "yes" man, though.
cons: Training is non existent, on the job and minimal at that.  Career advancement does not exist.  No performance bonuses.  No opportunities for growth.  Individual initiative is discouraged unless it's done management's way.    Many employees get pigeon holed, become stale in their skills and get trapped in this environment.  URMC is the new Kodak.  Also parking and communications are in great need of improvement.

review_title: Great atmosphere. Plenty of helpful services, supportive initiatives, and great health insurance.
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Rochester, NY
pros:
URMC is a great place to work because the building is like a mini-city. We have 3 cafeterias, a post office, convenience store, pharmacy, book store, a gym, and a bank as well as many other features and amenities. 
The management seems to really value employees & employee health and well-being. There are a number of university-sponsored initiatives to help improve life, reduce stress, maintain a healthy weight and exercise.
cons: Because the university is so large, it sometimes makes me feel a little secluded, because I work primarily independently and don't interact with many other people. However, I should point out that this is primarily due to my personality, and more outgoing people would certainly be able to interact more.

review_title: Exploitation of PhDs for low salary positions
pros: Good health benefits and access to health care.
cons: URMC is part of the problem with degradation of the value of an advanced degree.  I have a PhD and extensive postdoctoral experience at esteemed institutions.  My last position was professor level ($64K).  Before that I was a postdoc ($53K).  I was hired at URMC at $42K to do professor level work.  That seems to me like the university taking advantage of the hiring glut to underpay well-qualified scientists.

review_title: Mediocre office environment. Employer expectations far exceeded willingness on compensate monetarily.
pros: Excellent training and good benefits. Work environment is generally clean and well-kept. Computer programs used are fairly user friendly and staff is well-trained on how to use them. Employer expectations are clearly defined. The hours worked each week are usually kept at 40 and are basically 8-5. Some offices have Saturday hours but, if you are asked to work on Saturdays, you will receive other time off during the week to make up for it.
cons: Poor salary and frequently condescending management. Coworkers were regularly unprofessional and a good deal of time was spent containing problems, such as coworker mess-ups, long telephone wait-times, lost paperwork, etc. Doctors would frequently misplace forms dropped off by patients and secretarial staff had to take the fall for these errors.

review_title: Many possibilities if you are willing to look past cons for a bit
job_title: Clinical Lab Technician in Rochester, NY
pros: Benefits such as tuition waiver/ reimbursement and wellness programs, networking,  teaching hospital so a lot of new experiences and ability to learn, and transferring within the hospital is within reach. HR is helpful. Holiday and PTO is standard, but depending on department holiday celebrations are a nice touch. There are always incentives.
cons: Paying for parking but finding a spot in the lot that you pay for is also a daily hassle. Health care is kinda meh. I have a BS degree but the pay grade doesn’t match experience and skills.

pros: Ability to work with colleagues and engage in new areas of healthcare, research, etc.; Opportunities to share information especially with those who are not affected by their titles, degrees, and positions
cons: Too much hierarchy and attitudes of superiority due to the MD, PhD and title/degree status; poor management and very political especially in areas where nepotism ranks high; supervisors and managers too afraid to have real decisionmaking when it comes to personal time-off issues, flexible hours, etc.; Supervisors/management expect flexibility from the workers and are not very good at giving it to the employee (double standards exist)

pros: The U of R has great core resources for doing big science, if you have the budget to utilize them. The community is very open, accessible, and helpful. The U of R has two types of postdoctoral fellowships, and difference lies in the benefits. With an NIH funded salary line, you get to select healthcare benefits like every staff/professor employee. There is another category that gets benefits that more closely resemble the graduate students.
cons: You need to have independent funding to be considered for any faculty positions. No one will lead you by the nose, so you need to be your own advocate and make your career happen. Unlike other universities, postdocs are not considered "employees" in terms of benefit perks (UR considers postdocs to be trainees), like discounts for the Eastman community music school or retirement fund matching.

review_title: Enjoyed working here but pay is lacking
pros: Teamwork, opportunity for professional growth, tight-knit community, innovation
cons: The pay is, quite frankly, a bit insulting. UR needs to start focusing on adequately compensating their employees and allocate the necessary resources for proper staffing rather than shifting profits to inflated executive salaries who just want to spend more money on costly marketing campaigns. Expanded growth is taking over the regional market and it's difficult to find better paying jobs. Nursing management spread too thin. Staff continually asked to do more with less.

review_title: Wonderful company to work for that is held with high ethical standards.
pros: The University of Rochester Medical Center has terrific benefits from the moment you begin employment. It is the biggest employer of Rochester with many job openings.
cons: It is very hard, almost impossible to obtain a position within another department unless you know someone. I wanted to stay with this company but unfortunately, I could not advance and decided to move on as I was extremely unhappy with my role. After working at this company for a year, I had only received one 2% raise.

review_title: Rewarding and exciting place to work as long as you don't have to deal with management.
job_title: Clinical Technologist II in Rochester, NY
pros: Great facilities and resources. Up to date equipment. Opportunities to get involved in research. Great employee benefits and support.  Great reputation. Constant ongoing improvements are being made. Staff seems to be positive and have a good attitude.
cons: Opportunities for advancement depend greatly on position. Slow to hire new employees and fill open positions. Frequent short staffing. Highly political management. Management tends to not be open to suggestions, or slow and reluctant to institute new policies.

job_title: Laboratory Technician II in Rochester, NY
pros: As a lab tech the work is not difficult but there are a lot of chances to expand your skill set. Flexible hours depending on your supervisor and experiments that are going on.
cons: Training, leadership possibilities, etc. depends on your lab PI. In my experience if you want more responsibility you have to seek it and learn new techniques to get put on more projects. Again, this depends on your supervisor, but in the lab I worked in it was difficult for technicians to get more responsibility which limited the chances of getting mentioned in published papers. Pay is low but on par for lab techs and definitely depends on individual lab funding.

pros:
Great team ethic from most coworkers 
Diverse patient population 
Good food
Employee benefits 
Central location 
Nice place to start/find your rhythm
cons:
Not unionized 
Poor scheduling/odd scheduling 
Some nurses eat their young 
Poor staffing
Poor Parking availability
Not enough sick time & penalized for being sick

pros: Benefits, Location, Work Life Balance
cons: Culture, Salary, Pay For Performance Increases

pros: Teaching hospital and Trauma Center. Hired as a new graduate and oriented for a full year to the Emergency Department. Exceptional colleagues that are always there to lend a hand. Four weeks vacation given from the start. Excellent tuition reimbursement.
cons: High rate of turn over. Patient ratio of 6:1. High patient numbers. Orientation to all areas (i.e. triage, trauma, charge) takes a long time due to the turn over rate. Often asked by management for thoughts/ideas on employee satisfaction, but rarely see them implemented.

review_title: Great hospital in itself. However, My immediate manager gives the establishment a bad rep.
pros: Excellent patient care. Professional growth is encouraged on a unit level.
cons: Speaking from a personal point of view and experience, if you cannot and will not carry news to the manager's office, you will find yourself in her bad book to the point of some nurses getting fired without a valid reason. management is never visible to learn anything about her  staff, rather depend on information gathered from chosen few. management despise suggestions from staff then in the end roll out the plan as her own.

review_title: Great for early career experience- laboratory technician
job_title: Laboratory Technician III in Rochester, NY
pros:
The benefits were good. Great health insurance, dental insurance, the university invests in your retirement after 2 years, there were free health and wellness programs, formal workplace conflict resolution programs, free counseling, cheap gym membership (on site).
My employer invested in my career development, paying for graduate level courses, and funding my trip to national conferences.
I received a lot of mentoring from faculty in my department.
The administrative staff was very effective, organized, and efficient. Great coworkers.
The pay was okay for the cost of living in Rochester.
cons:
Conflicts between individuals made the workplace stressful.
The weather has a negative effect on individuals' general sense of well-being

job_title: Technical Associate I in Rochester, NY
pros:
The city provides many discounts for URMC employees, i.e apartment rent. 
The university provides healthcare benefits, but they are not great.
cons: As expected from an academic institution, where money comes mainly from government funds, the financial part is very stingy. As such, it is expected from lower-tier scientists to work long hours for minimum pay (no pay for overtime either). Depending on the department, the working environment could be hostile/stressful.

review_title: Not all it is cracked up to be
pros: In-depth training, great health benefits, PTO, tuition reimbursement after 1 year
cons: Even though U of R is the area's largest employer, it's not all it's cracked up to be. The organization is purchasing existing medical practices and urgent care facilities at a rapid pace and the growth is not without trouble. When the staff of these practices become U of R employees there isn't much commitment to the organization. The loyalty remains to the physician who sold his practice yet still works there. Makes it impossible to succeed if you're a U of R employee put into one of these situations.

review_title: Learned a lot while working at URMC
job_title: Laboratory Technician IV in Rochester, NY
pros:
Excellent benefit, including tuition benefits. 

Great place to work in research laboratory to gain research skills. 

Flexible hours to some degree.

New research facilities are amazing. 

Excellent reputation and the largest employer in the Rochester, NY area.
cons:
Parking can be inconvenient, had to drive pass work to get to parking lot and then take a 5-10 minute shuttle ride to campus.  

Not much room to advance without a higher degree, at least in the research realm.

Compared to working in the research industry, compensation is less than normal but compared to other academic research centers, compensation is average.

job_title: Medical Technologist II in Rochester, NY
pros: They used to have really great tuition benefits and that is the only reason I stayed with the medical center
cons: Middle managers are complacent and don't care.  Most supervisors and managers are promoted not based on ability but based on tenure. Not a great place to work unless you are a nurse or physician. They also are taking away benefits due to the new health care reform.

review_title: A great place to work in the wrong place
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Rochester, NY
pros: The university of Rochester is an excellent working environment, with good facilities on campus for staff, career development opportunities and access to research facilities. The university also provides housing for staff in the vicinities of campus at affordable prices, which is particularly good for newcomers moving in from abroad.
cons: Rochester has a good standard of living, however is more of a family-friendly suburban city and doesn't offer a lot for young single people. Opportunities to socialize are very scarce, and the very tough winter weather makes it very hard to live there alone.

review_title: Riding the fumes of their reputation
job_title: Help Desk Technician in Rochester, NY
pros: There were some good problem-solving opportunities and interesting projects.  It's a solid job that isn't likely to be outsourced or downsized.  Most of my coworkers were fun to work with, but they are leaving due to the cons.
cons:
The ISD help desk is no longer a foot in the door that lets you step into a better job at URMC.  You will not get into a good technical position by starting at the help desk.  They are more likely to hire outside the company for openings in areas like system administration, networking, and security.  If they do hire internally, it is generally based on nepotism and cronyism.  There is a shocking amount of incompetence rampant in the whole of ISD.  They had to scramble to find money to pay people when they forgot to include them in the budget.  Pet projects are pushed through at the expense of people, sound technological practices, and the needs of the business.  Office politics and group think ensure poor decision making.

Benefits (including tuition assistance) are reduced pretty much every year.  They have drastically reduced wages for new employees.  To make people accept terrible pay, they give promises about future raises that turn out to only be a nickle an hour increase.  Even the higher level positions are grossly underpaid.  Like $40,000 for a system admin or network admin underpaid.

They allowed people in positions of power over the help desk to abuse and sexually harass employees for years in addition to violating state and federal labor laws.  Instead of firing the perpetrator and those complicit, the person was just moved to be in charge of a smaller group (most of whom subsequently quit).  One of the participants is still at the help desk stealing credit for the work of the staff if the participant thinks they can get away with it.  Even if they can't get away with claiming the work as theirs, quality is not often recognized.  One person in a decision-making position needs to have things explained multiple times before there is even the possibility of understanding.

This is a job with many frustrations and few bright spots.  Oh, and the interesting projects mentioned in the pros section are only for favored employees.

job_title: Registered Nurse II in Rochester, NY
pros: Great academic environment research facility with incredibly interesting medical research happening. Great people. I work in medicine and on average, the quality of person I work with is above average. Lots of opportunities for learning, growing your knowledge base.
cons: Big disconnect between upper and mid/lower management. Can be challenging to advance. Salaries stink and increases do not keep pace with inflation. Many people leave to "adjust" their salary, only to return at more honest pay. HR insults your intelligence by touting your "total compensation" as a way to make your "pay"seem OK, but in reality it is all smoke and mirrors. Internal departmental moves are often done laterally or for LESS pay, even though the work is more responsibility. There is a very nebulous "salary grade" system in place to attach pay to positions, but the average employee is not privy to what the grades represent. If you are looking internally for a position, you need to ask your direct supervisor for the "salary grades" and what dollar amounts they capture. As I learned , some salary grades are completely out of skew for the positions they represent (ie all the peopl in a particular department make significantly MORE than the grade for the job they are doing).

review_title: Great learning environment, tuition benefits, lack of advancement opportunities
pros: Smart co-workers that care immensely about what they do. Opportunity to learn a lot - free scientific presentations on special topics occur regualrly throughout the year. Tuition benefit program is a nice perk.
cons: Difficult to advance. Decisions are required to be sent up the chain - even small ones; slows productivity. Low amount of paid vacation time and typically only seven holidays throughout the whole year.

job_title: Data Control Clerk in Rochester, NY
pros: Given opportunities to go beyond job description; research analysts are given opportunity to write manuscripts, perform data analysis, write grants
cons: The University of Rochester Medical Center underpays their employees; they are the only major research institution in the area so they practically have a monopoly over the region; poor benefits; not much room for upward growth within each department

review_title: Overall I enjoy what I do, it's the politics of the institution that get in the way.
job_title: Health Project Coordinator in Rochester, NY
pros: The benefits are really great. Health insurance and 4013b/Roth ira match is excellent. Tuition waiver program is also amazing: 90-95% covered.
cons: The UofR is very siloed. It is hard to get departments to work well with each other. This can make working there difficult since there is a necessity for cross-departmental collaboration.

review_title: gained great experience but job satisfaction depended a lot on what lab you worked in
pros:
well respected in the community
work with really great and intelligent people
pay is usually pretty good but annual raises are not
cons:
parking gets more and more expensive every year
senior management doesn't deal with serious problems in the labs
employees can often be hung out to dry if they lodge complaints
annual raises have been pretty small in the last few years

job_title: Lab Technician II in Rochester, NY
pros: Great company ethos, friendly, good benefits, many jobs to aspire to internally. Supportive culture, education benefits foster advancement. If you know where you want to go in medical, this job can help you get there. Many nursing students, premed students and biology majors begin here. Many lab technologists start as lab techs while studying then transition fairly easily to internal roles.
cons: Low starting  but good relative to cost of living, parking is scarce and expensive. Smaller city but still much to offer relative to size. Harsh winters.

pros: The staff at Strong Memorial Hospital are extremely dedicated at all levels. Everyone really cares for your well-being despite the hectic schedules and sick patient population. It really is a function of the very warm nature of people of Upstate NY.
cons: This can be a busy place to work with very complicated, sick patients who may require more effort and time than is designated.

job_title: Analyst Programmer Senior in Rochester, NY
pros: The benefits are decent. The work environment is laid back.  the rest of this is to fill out your 20 word minimum
cons: Salaries for programmer analysts are extremely low even given the fact that it is in upstate NY and the cost of living is low.  I know of other programmers who make nearly double the rate for less qualified positions.

review_title: A wonderful place to work, with less than average compensation.

cons: Unintelligent, Catty upper management. Compensation is not equal to work force norms, and many are under paid. Parking is horrible.

review_title: It is a congenial collaborative work environment that fosters networking among scientists with diverse expertise.
job_title: Research Assistant Professor in Rochester, NY
pros: Multi disciplinary research favors collaborations among scientists with diverse areas of expertise. Many renowned scientists including several Nobel Laureates are invited for talks each year and the community is exposed to trending areas in science.
cons: Internal funding opportunities for early career scientists are limited. Some departments are not as well managed as others.

review_title: Flexible work schedule but high turnover in the Autolab

Never a dull moment on weekdays evening shift.

Free tuition at the University of Rochester.

Frequently short-staffed due to people leaving or retiring.
The churn rate is quite high. Experienced techs often leave for greener pastures, so they are always training new people.
Toxic people at the workplace are not dealt with even after frequent complaints to management.

review_title: Absolutely the worst place I have ever worked or lived.
pros:
*If you are lucky enough to get sick, you get 60 days off with pay.
* Working here is a good motivator for a change of career.
* Working here will make you think fondly of the job that you used to think was the worst place to work...before you came here.
cons:
* E-mailing people in departments to get some information will generally get you no response.
*parking is ridiculous. The parking "authority" is even more so. 
* Pay is way below other places.
*Rochester,NY is the worst city I have ever lived in.

review_title: Used to a good place to work. Seems lost and chaotic now with no value placed on talent

cons: Low salary, disjointed organization structure, leadership lacks vision, all decisions governed not by business value but potential financial gifts. Faculty tries to run the business creating chaos and string of terrible decisions

pros: Great atmosphere, great feel of small town community. Further education encouraged and reward but not a requirement. A great place to learn and experience a lot.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Rochester, NY

cons: I haven't seen a lot of mixing between labs, though there is a postdoctoral group that gathers socially every month or so.

review_title: URMC is a great place to work

pros: Very positive attitude while in the work place. Very friendly and open.
cons: The department I worked in required every abnormal hours and since it was dealing with the research animals, you needed to get used to the smell of animal bedding. The smell wasn't so pleasant and still till this day when I smell it, I get really bad memories of feeling nauseous.

pros:
Great laboratory with open space lab and big windows, very easy to work environment. 
Flexible time working time.
Supportive lab members, PIs, and administrative stuff to work with.
cons:
Cold and long winters can really be a bit inhibiting for some people.

review_title: Too Many Chiefs, Not Enough Indians
pros: Values are excellent..just wish they'd stand by what they say and the value system that they created. Really respected my coworkers... WE created an awesome team environment.
cons: Way too many managers. They hire new management and promote managers to Directors positions, etc. like crazy instead of hiring more regular staff. They have a ridiculous number of managers and supervisors...starting with Human Resources. I didn't realize it until I filled in for my boss at their regular management meeting, it was unbelievable. The only reason I stayed so long was that I built solid, positive, professional relationships with my coworkers. They were the best. Other than that, the hospital politics, favoritism and unprofessionalism among management drove me out. No matter if management is wrong, they will be supported and protected. The annual merit increases are an absolute joke. You work hard throughout the year making a difference in your position...I mean, really making strides only to get the same flat percentage that someone else performing at a mediocre level receives. Have a problem? Want to discuss an issue or an idea? Don't bother going to HR. You'll get lip service and no results.

job_title: Lab Technician III in Rochester, NY
pros: Great health and dental insurance options, and retirement plans. Easy to get hired within the organization once you have your foot in the door.
cons:
No room for advancement unless you have a PhD or an MD.
Not a lot of funding for most laboratories.. at least half a dozen labs left the university during my time of employment (about 8 months) and it doesn't look to be getting any better.

pros: Great research facilities and staff. The amount of labs, types of collaboration, as well as the supplies. libraries, and classrooms make it a five star place

review_title: a pretty good experience. there's always a lot to learn.
